title: (x) Berlin Schoenefeld / sans for airport - Foundry Sterling {Jan}
content:
Hello,  
does anyone recognise this? I found it here, in an article about the new Berlin Shoenfeld airport: [http://www.nytimes.com/2010/03/09/world/europe/09berlin.html?src=tptw](http://web.archive.org/web/20130618031656/http:/www.nytimes.com/2010/03/09/world/europe/09berlin.html?src=tptw "http://www.nytimes.com/2010/03/09/world/europe/09berlin.html?src=tptw")  
It looks like a lot of things, but isn't any of them. It isn't Bliss, Kievit, Myriad ... help!
author: typofoto

comments.content:
Sorry, here's the image I'm interested in

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20130618031656im_/http:/typophile.com/files/09berlin_CA0-popup2_5086.jpg)

Sorry everyone, I can't get the image to upload. It's the first image in this article [http://www.nytimes.com/2010/03/09/world/europe/09berlin.html?src=tptw](http://web.archive.org/web/20130618031656/http:/www.nytimes.com/2010/03/09/world/europe/09berlin.html?src=tptw "http://www.nytimes.com/2010/03/09/world/europe/09berlin.html?src=tptw"), with the word "Berlin." backwards.
Oh, and btw, I’d say it is Kievit.

Jan,  
thanks for your help with the image, much appreciated. That's the one.  
Kievit is very close, but the junction on the "n" is higher on the image than Kievit's.

Seems to be some corporate font for the berlin airports.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20130618031656im_/http:/typophile.com/files/berliner_flughafen_4092.jpg)

Jan,  
thanks again. Where did you find that information?  
Alex

It’s Foundry Sterling.  
Look here:  
 [http://www.berlin-airport.de/DE/GeschaeftskundenUndPartner/AgenturenDien...](http://web.archive.org/web/20130618031656/http:/www.berlin-airport.de/DE/GeschaeftskundenUndPartner/AgenturenDienstleister/FarbeSchrift/index.html "http://www.berlin-airport.de/DE/GeschaeftskundenUndPartner/AgenturenDienstleister/FarbeSchrift/index.html")  
(Download Pdf: Schriften der Berliner Flughäfen)

Never mind, it's on their website (where I should have looked to begin with).  
Does anyone know anything about it?

Sorry, cross post.  
Thanks Jan, that's very helpful.
